sentences: Muck like his [[ Hugo award | /m/03gw9 ]] winning [[ Spin | /m/0dqj6b ]] , [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] 's The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] is all about a mysterious event that happens out of nowhere and has the entire world at attention trying to figure out what it all means.

Nonetheless, it's an honor to be a finalist, and delightful to see several other things on the ballot I was involved in publishing: in the Best Novel category, [[ Ken MacLeod | /m/04dkw ]] 's audacious, funny, and deeply intelligent [[ Cosmonaut Keep | /m/03h2hc0 ]] and [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] 's spooky, evocative, and unforgettable The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] , both of which I acquired for [[ Tor | /m/035qh3 ]] ; in Best Novella, [[ Vernor Vinge | /m/07zl1 ]] 's  Fast Times at Fairmont High,  the single new story in the [[ Tor | /m/035qh3 ]] collection The Collected Stories of Vernor Vinge; and, in Best Novelette, [[ Ted Chiang | /m/01w2bh ]] 's stunning   [[ Hell | /m/0d2l53 ]] is the Absence of God  from my own anthology Starlight 3. Voted on and awarded along with the [[ Hugo | /m/0d1b_ ]] is the [[ John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer | /m/01b8bn ]] ; among this year's finalists are [[ Alexander C. Irvine | /m/027_c78 ]]

Saturday, June 15 A lazy day: I read another [[ Hugo | /m/03gw9 ]] nominee, [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] by [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]]  but was unable to find the others on Stephen's shelves so I made do with some other stuff

Muck like his [[ Hugo award | /m/03gw9 ]] winning [[ Spin | /m/0dqj6b ]] , [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] 's The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] is all about a mysterious event that happens out of nowhere and has the entire world at attention trying to figure out what it all means

[[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] won a 2002 John W. Campbell Award for his previous novel, The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] ; [[ Charles de Lint | /m/026srm ]] was guest of honour in [[ Florida | /m/02xry ]] at this year's International Conference for the [[ Fantastic | /m/04zx37 ]] in the [[ Arts | /m/05nj3v ]] ; [[ Spider Robinson | /m/01d5wx ]] was toastmaster at the [[ World Science Fiction Convention | /m/081qw ]] held in [[ Toronto | /m/0h7h6 ]] over [[ Labour Day | /m/04l7_ ]] , where [[ Robert J. Sawyer | /m/01q_6y ]] won a [[ Hugo Award | /m/03gw9 ]] for [[ Hominids | /m/040vl3_ ]] , the first title of a short series about an alternative world occupied by sentient [[ Neanderthals | /m/0cbc6 ]] , now completed in the [[ SF | /m/06n90 ]] novel under review.
Although I've looked in on some discussions of [[ Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] 's previous effort [[ Darwinia | /m/050ltz ]] , The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] is the first of his novels that I've read

? [[ Jack Williamson | /m/01_kcg ]] 's [[ Terraforming Earth | /m/04205s8 ]] and [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] 's The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]]  tied for this year's [[ John W. Campbell Memorial Award | /m/01bb1c ]] for the best science fiction novel of 2001, while [[ Andy Duncan | /m/0c44wr ]] 's   [[ The Chief Designer | /m/05b3hfp ]]    won the [[ Theodore Sturgeon Award | /m/08t6_c ]] for the best short [[ SF | /m/06n90 ]] of the year.

Nonetheless, it?s an honor to be a finalist, and delightful to see several other things on the ballot I was involved in publishing: in the Best Novel category, [[ Ken MacLeod | /m/04dkw ]] ?s audacious, funny, and deeply intelligent [[ Cosmonaut Keep | /m/03h2hc0 ]] and [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] ?s spooky, evocative, and unforgettable The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] , both of which I acquired for [[ Tor | /m/035qh3 ]] ; in Best Novella, [[ Vernor Vinge | /m/07zl1 ]] ?s ?Fast Times at Fairmont High,? the single new story in the [[ Tor | /m/035qh3 ]] collection The Collected Stories of Vernor Vinge; and, in Best Novelette, [[ Ted Chiang | /m/01w2bh ]] ?s stunning ? [[ Hell | /m/0d2l53 ]] is the Absence of God? from my own anthology Starlight 3. Voted on and awarded along with the [[ Hugo | /m/0d1b_ ]] is the [[ John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer | /m/01b8bn ]] ; among this year?s finalists are [[ Alexander C. Irvine | /m/027_c78 ]]

Other works short-listed by the [[ Sunburst Award | /m/05x7py ]] committee included [[ Paradigm | /m/017q0c ]] of [[ Earth | /m/02j71 ]] by Candas Jane Dorsey, [[ The Kappa Child | /m/04w3124 ]] by [[ Hiromi Goto | /m/01n45h ]] , Salamander by [[ Thomas Wharton | /m/0cf72s ]] and [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] by [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]]

Chad Orzel, Trent Goulding, and the [[ Hugo | /m/03gw9 ]] nominators had fairly positive things to say about [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] 's The [[ Chronoliths | /m/03b2n8 ]] , and [[ Chad | /m/01p1b ]] managed to clear up my misconception that [[ Robert Charles Wilson | /m/01dhxm ]] was [[ Robert Anton Wilson | /m/06hgj ]] , so I thought I'd give the book a whirl

sentences: [[ Nicholas Saunders | /m/0fzsd3 ]] , author of [[ E for Ecstasy | /m/03ctqs ]] , [[ Ecstasy | /m/06lf6y2 ]] and the Dance Culture and the forthcoming Dance, Trance and Transformation, donated $1,650 to [[ MAPS | /m/01fg39 ]] for the study
[[ E for Ecstasy | /m/03ctqs ]]  was written by [[ Nicholas Saunders | /m/0fzsd3 ]] and published in May 1993.
Wife of deceased [[ Nicholas Saunders | /m/0fzsd3 ]] , the author of [[ E for Ecstasy | /m/03ctqs ]] , Anja takes an in-depth look at the links between mainstream faiths and drugs.

[[ Nicholas Saunders | /m/0fzsd3 ]] , author of the book [[ E for Ecstasy | /m/03ctqs ]] , cites a [[ Benedictine | /m/01cfj ]] monk who finds [[ MDMA | /m/02qpq ]]  opens up a direct channel to [[ God | /m/0d05l6 ]]  . [[ MDMA | /m/02qpq ]] may not be  Christ in chemical form , but if it had been present in the [[ Eucharist | /m/02np4 ]] , then we would all still be devout [[ Christians | /m/04t_mf ]] , possibly for ever.

[[ GLOSS | /m/0p5rbvj ]] >> the semi-Australian  21st Century culture  mag 21C          was shaping up to be the legible  [[ Mondo 2000 | /m/046pjx ]] , but now it's          taken its emulation perhaps a step too far and ceased          publication altogether... still, arguably a better fate          than actually being taken over by  [[ RU Sirius | /m/034q7c ]] , as seems to          have befallen music-and-fashion cyber-nonsense AXCESS...          other recent casualties include the second incarnation of          the frankly hilarious  [[ SPY | /m/02vnz ]] , a closure ominously presaged by          regular readers' letters bemoaning their inability to          understand its urbane  [[ New York | /m/02_286 ]]  witticisms... on a more          upbeat note , aspiring  [[ Net | /m/03nnjx5 ]]  journo Garret Keogh          informs us that  [[ Flamingo | /m/0163q8 ]]            is the code name for new launch COMPUTER ACTIVE, due out          any day now and apparently helmed by Jan Howells, formerly          of  [[ Ziff-Davis | /m/02882_ ]] 's doomed Computer Life... new cover of  [[ SPIN | /m/02wmv9 ]]           features  [[ South Park | /m/06y_n ]] 's  [[ Eric Cartman | /m/0myj0 ]] ,  [[ Janet Jackson | /m/0gbwp ]] -style,          and hopefully gives info on the filthy animators' upcoming          feature film... back over here, .NET has caught up with           [[ South Park | /m/06y_n ]]  , but then goes and spoils it all with a          profile of its 3 top female Quake players, all from the  [[ US | /m/09c7w0 ]]           , and an insufficiently detailed apology about the           barrage of offensive email  sent to subscribers of the          hacked netmag-news mailing list ... and finally,  [[ RADIO TIMES | /m/02495p ]]  continues its very public struggle with font          substitution errors - that is, unless they *want* those          subheads printed in tightly tracked  [[ Courier | /m/02p63c ]]  ...          and this week runs a complaint from one of  [[ Britain | /m/07ssc ]] 's          biggest slash fans -  - about  plot          holes  in the recent  [[ Blake's 7 | /m/0hhkw ]]  radio play ;          presumably not enough  Beat Up And Rape Avon  scenes for          their liking...                                       ,,             [[ Nicholas Saunders | /m/0fzsd3 ]] , the entrepreneur behind  [[ Alternative London | /m/06nksw3 ]] , numerous Neal's Yard companies (including one of          the first DTP one-stop-shops in the  [[ UK | /m/07ssc ]] ), the author of   [[ E for Ecstasy | /m/03ctqs ]]  ,   [[ Ecstasy Reconsidered | /m/03ctqs ]]  , and most recently the          man behind , was killed in a car accident on          Tuesday.
